questions.text: What are adenoids also known as?
questions.solution: Adenoids are commonly known as nasopharyngeal tonsil. It is situated at the junction of the roof and posterior wall of the nasopharynx.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the structure marked as A?

choices.text: It is part of the Waldeyer's ring
Hypertrophies up to the age of 6 years and starts to regress from puberty
It is surrounded by a capsule

questions.solution:
The structure marked A is the adenoids. It is not surrounded by a capsule.

Adenoids are comprised of vertical ridges of lymphoid tissues separated by deep clefts. They form the superior aspect of Waldeyer's ring. They have no crypts and no capsule, unlike palatine tonsils which have both.

It is present at birth, enlarges up to the age of 6 years, and then starts regressing from puberty. It completely disappears by the age of 20 years.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the signs and symptoms of the condition represented below?
questions.solution:
The given x-ray shows enlarged adenoids and suggests the diagnosis of adenoid hypertrophy. Patients show an absent nasolabial fold.

Clinical features:

  • Nasal obstruction is the most common symptom. This leads to mouth breathing. Nasal obstruction also interferes with feeding or suckling in a child. As respiration and feeding cannot take place simultaneously, a child with adenoid enlargement fails to thrive.
  • Nasal discharge, sinusitis, and epistaxis.
  • Bilateral conductive hearing loss and serous otitis media due to eustachian tube obstruction.
  • Rhinolalia clausa - hyponasal voice.
  • Adenoid facies - elongated face with a dull expression, pinched up nose, absent nasolabial crease, open mouth, prominent and crowded upper teeth.
  • Sleep apnoea - chronic cases lead to hypoxemia and pulmonary vasoconstriction. This consequently leads to pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale.
  • Aprosexia - lack of concentration.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to you by her mother with complaints of mouth breathing. She has a flat, expressionless long face with an open mouth. On examination, a high arched palate and crowded upper teeth are noted. What is the voice abnormality that can be noted in this child?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a child with adenoid facies is suggestive of a diagnosis of adenoid hypertrophy. Rhinolalia clausa/ hyponasal voice can be seen in these patients. 

It is also seen in conditions like common cold, nasal allergy, etc.

Option A - Hot potato voice is a muffled and thick speech often seen in a peritonsillar abscess (quinsy).

Option C - Rhinolalia aperta causes a hypernasal voice.

Option D - Staccato voice or scanning speech is a broken speech seen in cerebellar lesions as well as multiple sclerosis.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought by his mother to the ENT OPD with frequent upper respiratory tract infections. His mother gives a history of loud snoring at night and posterior rhinoscopy examination shows enlarged adenoids. Which of the following will you not advise in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Beta 2 agonists have no role in conditions of upper airway obstruction like adenoid hypertrophy. They are bronchodilators used in lower airway obstructive diseases.

When symptoms of adenoid hypertrophy are not marked, breathing exercises, decongestant nasal drops, and antihistamines for any coexisting nasal allergy can cure the condition without resorting to surgery.

Marked adenoid hypertrophy with associated complications can be treated with adenoidectomy and grommet insertion.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for an adenoidectomy procedure?

choices.text: Recurrent middle ear infections with deafness

questions.solution:
Multiple adenoids is not an indication for adenoidectomy.

Indications of adenoidectomy:

  • Adenoid hypertrophy causing snoring, mouth breathing, sleep apnoea syndrome or speech abnormalities, i.e. (rhinolalia clausa)
  • Recurrent rhinosinusitis
  • Chronic otitis media with effusion associated with adenoid hyperplasia
  • Recurrent ear discharge in benign CSOM associated with adenoiditis/adenoid hyperplasia
  • Dental malocclusion. Adenoidectomy does not correct dental abnormalities but will prevent its recurrence after orthodontic treatment

questions.text: A 6-year-old child has been posted for an adenoidectomy procedure. Which of the following conditions if present in this child will be a contraindication to performing the surgery?
questions.solution:
Cleft palate is a contraindication to perform adenoidectomy as removal of adenoids causes velopharyngeal insufficiency. 

Velopharyngeal insufficiency is a condition where the soft palate does not close tightly against the back of the throat. This leads to air coming out the nose (characterized by hypernasality) during speech. 

Contraindications for adenoidectomy:

  • Cleft palate or submucous palate. 
  • Hemorrhagic diathesis.
  • Acute infection of the upper respiratory tract.

questions.text: A school-going child presents with a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, mouth breathing, and impaired hearing. On examination, a high arched palate is noted. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of adenoid hypertrophy. The best line of management is adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

A grommet is inserted to provide continued aeration of middle ear and used in cases where fluid collection recurs.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy diagnosed with adenoid hypertrophy has undergone an adenoidectomy procedure. Two weeks following the procedure, he developed Grisel syndrome. What is the reason for this condition?
questions.solution:
Grisel syndrome involves paraspinal muscle spasm that occurs post adenoidectomy.

Grisel syndrome refers to non-traumatic atlantoaxial joint subluxation. The patient complains of neck pain and develops torticollis. It is mostly due to spasm of paraspinal muscles but can also be due to atlantoaxial dislocation requiring cervical collar and even traction.

Thornwaldt cyst is located in the midline of the posterior wall of the nasopharynx in the adenoid mass.

It is an epithelial-lined median recess found within the adenoid mass and extends from pharyngeal mucosa to the periosteum of the basiocciput. It represents the attachment of notochord to the pharyngeal endoderm during embryonic life.

When infected, it may be the cause of persistent postnasal discharge or crusting. Sometimes an abscess can form in the bursa (Thornwaldt’s disease). It is managed surgically by marsupialization of the swelling and complete removal of the lining of the cyst.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient has a Thornwaldt abscess that got infected from a Thornwaldtâ€™s cyst. Which of the following will you not recommend for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
Antitubercular treatment has no role in the treatment of Thornwaldt’s abscess.

Thornwaldt’s abscess is formed due to the infection of Thornwaldt cyst. Treatment includes administration of antibiotics to treat the infection and marsupialization of the cystic swelling. There should be adequate removal of its lining membrane.
